thread.title: Michael Wilbon says Cubs' loss not as disappointing as usual
thread.title_full: Michael Wilbon says Cubs' loss not as disappointing as usual | Chicago Sun-Times

title: Michael Wilbon says Cubs' loss not as disappointing as usual
text:
ESPN personality and Chicago sports fan Michael Wilbon isn’t as depressed today as he usually is when the Cubs are eliminated from the postseason.
Speaking on “ The Dan Patrick Show ,” Wilbon said “I’m not in usual Cubs’ depression. It feels like it’s the beginning. … People are not moping. It’s not like other postseason losses where people are plunged into depression.”
Watch the complete Michael Wilbon interview:
Wilbon cited the young team and manager Joe Maddon as reasons why he isn’t as disappointed as he was, say, back in 2003 when the Cubs lost the NLCS in seven games.
In fact, Wilbon is so over the loss that he’s already thrown his support behind the NL-champion Mets – who eliminated the Cubs in four games.
Maybe there's room on the W.S. Bandwagon for a Cubs fan…
— Michael Wilbon (@RealMikeWilbon) October 22, 2015
So Chicago, how depressing was last night’s loss? Tweet us at @suntimes_sports.
24 of the best photos from the Cubs’ postseason: Start Slideshow » Michael Wilson ins't as disappointed as he usually is after a Cubs postseason loss.
Anthony Rizzo #44 of the Chicago Cubs catches a foul ball hit by Travis d'Arnaud #7 of the New York Mets to end the sixth inning during Game 2 of the 2015 MLB National League Championship Series at Citi Field on October 18, 2015 in the Flushing neighborhood of the Queens borough of New York City. (Photo by Al Bello/Getty Images)
Jake Arrieta #49 of the Chicago Cubs reacts after defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates to win the National League Wild Card game at PNC Park on October 7, 2015 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The Chicago Cubs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates with a score of 4 to 0. (Photo by Jared Wickerham/Getty Images)
